subject: RE: [junit] Test case strategy for complex tests
msgSnippet: For #1 it seems that the tests need to answer the following questions: A) Are the beans generating the correct SQL? B) Are the queries being called correctly?
messageBody:
For #1 it seems that the tests need to answer the following questions:
A) Are the beans generating the correct SQL?
B) Are the queries being called correctly?
C) Are the results being mapped to objects correctly?

You may be able to write tests that answer these questions without
processing a large amount of data. For example, for 'A' you don't even
need to issue the query. Just write tests that verify the SQL. Mock
objects help here.

For 'B' and 'C' You might also try using a database that has a small,
known subset of data in it so you don't need to process as much, or use
a mock database.

In #2 again, it appears that the primary concern of the tests may be
validating the SQL that is generated and not what is returned by the
call, but I could be wrong.

>
> I'm writing test cases for EJB's and some of the beans do
> some complex SQL
> generation and return large amounts of data, Realizing that
> test cases should be
> simple... Should I just test that the query runs without
> error and not worry about the
> return? Or should I check certain parts to make sure thay
> are right? Or check the
> entire result set?
>
> Question#2: I have many SQL queries with multiple
> possiblities in the WHERE clause.
> They are being built on the fly based on the search criteria
> given by a user. I was
> going to test each WHERE clause in a seperate test. Should I
> write the tests in such a
> way that I could combine calls to them and have a test case
> that is more of a
> controller pattern?
> pseudo code as follows
> <code>
> public void combinedTest1(){
> SearchVO search = buildSearchVO ( add two parameters);
>
> performSearchTest(search);
>
> search = buildSearchVO(two other parameters);
>
> performSearchTest(search);
> }</code>
>
>
